unnormalised: **Automotive: Understanding New Traffic Regulations for a Smoother Ride**
normalised: Automotive: Understanding New Traffic Regulations for a Smoother Ride

unnormalised: New Delhi – Driving in India is about to get more regulated. The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has recently announced updated traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety and reducing congestion.
normalised: New Delhi – Driving in India is about to get more regulated. The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has recently announced updated traffic regulations aimed at improving road safety and reducing congestion.

unnormalised: One key change is the stricter enforcement of lane discipline. Drivers caught weaving through lanes without signaling can now face fines starting from Rs. 500. The regulations also mandate stricter penalties for using mobile phones while driving; first-time offenders could face a penalty of Rs. 1000.
normalised: One key change is the stricter enforcement of lane discipline. Drivers caught weaving through lanes without signaling can now face fines starting from rupee five hundred. The regulations also mandate stricter penalties for using mobile phones while driving; first-time offenders could face a penalty of rupee one thousand.

unnormalised: Inspired by traffic awareness campaigns frequently highlighted in Bollywood films like "Traffic," the regulations also place greater emphasis on pedestrian safety. Motorists failing to yield to pedestrians at zebra crossings will face hefty fines.
normalised: Inspired by traffic awareness campaigns frequently highlighted in Bollywood films like "Traffic," the regulations also place greater emphasis on pedestrian safety. Motorists failing to yield to pedestrians at zebra crossings will face hefty fines.

unnormalised: Additionally, the permissible speed limit on certain expressways has been revised. The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) has been directed to install clearly visible signage indicating the updated speed limits. Expect reduced speed limits in accident-prone areas and near school zones. For instance, speed limits near DPS Mathura Road are now capped at 40 km/h.

Expect reduced speed limits in accident-prone areas and near school zones. For instance, speed limits near D P S Mathura Road are now capped at forty kilometer per hour.

unnormalised: Authorities plan to use increased CCTV surveillance and e-challan systems to improve enforcement across major cities like Mumbai, Kolkata, and Chennai. These new rules aim to bring about a safer and more organized driving environment for all.
